sections.content: Voting is the cornerstone of democracy, allowing citizens to express their preferences for leaders, policies, and laws shaping their communities and countries. In this lesson, we will explore the mechanics of elections, examine different voting systems, and discuss the importance of civic participation.
sections.title: Introduction to Voting

sections.content: Elections serve as a fundamental mechanism in democracies, enabling citizens to choose representatives and leaders. They ensure accountability and provide a peaceful transfer of power. By reflecting the will of the people, elections uphold democratic principles and allow citizens to influence decisions and policies.
sections.title: The Purpose of Elections

sections.content:
Different voting systems are used globally to determine election outcomes:

1. **First-Past-The-Post (FPTP):** A candidate wins by having the most votes, even if it's not a majority. Common in the US and Canada.
2. **Proportional Representation (PR):** Votes allocate seats proportionally to parties based on their share of the vote, ensuring broader representation. Used in many European countries.
3. **Ranked Choice Voting (RCV):** Voters rank candidates by preference. If no majority is achieved, votes are redistributed until a winner emerges. Increasingly adopted in modern elections.
sections.title: Types of Voting Systems

sections.content: Civic participation, including voting, is essential for a thriving democracy. It empowers citizens to voice opinions and influence government actions. Active engagement fosters community and ensures representation for diverse perspectives. High voter turnout strengthens democracy, while low turnout risks decisions unreflective of the majority.
sections.title: Why Civic Participation Matters
